Chapter Ninety: Concerning the Gnosis of the Obligatory Duties and the Supererogatory Acts

Indeed, the obligatory duties (*al-fara'id*) are like riding beasts, and the supererogatory acts (*al-sunan*) / are the path leading them to their ultimate goals.

If you traverse the path, you become an obligatory duty (*farida*), / and thus you become the Hearing of the Real (*al-Haqq*) in its signs.

This is the opposite of the supererogatory acts (*al-nawafil*); so reflect upon them and adhere / to the paths of virtues, striving diligently to establish them.

### [The Individual Obligation, the Communal Obligation, the Conditional Obligation]

Obligatory Duties (*al-fara'id*) are the acts or abstentions that God Almighty has made incumbent upon His servants, making them definitive, and punishing whoever fails to perform them. They are of two types: the Individual Obligation (*fard 'ayn*), which is not waived from the individual even if others perform it; and the Communal Obligation (*fard kifaya*), which is waived from the individual if others perform it. Before others perform it, it is incumbent upon him and upon those others, such as the funeral prayer, washing the dead, and *Jihad*. There is a third obligation that appears between these two, having a connection to each, yet differing in ruling from the other. An example is the obligatory Hajj if one is unable to perform it. Although one is not addressed by it except with the condition of ability (*istita'a*), it is an obligation dependent upon its condition. If his guardian performs Hajj on his behalf, it is waived from him, and he receives the reward for the performance. This is not the case with the Communal Obligation (*fard kifaya*) because of the existence of the reward [for the performer], nor is it like the obligatory prayer because it is not waived from the one on whose behalf it is prayed. Thus, it resembles neither the obligatory prayer nor the Communal Obligation.

### [The Supererogatory Acts are Two Types: A Sunna Commanded by the Messenger and a Sunna Innovated by a Member of the Community]

As for the Supererogatory Acts (*al-sunan*), they are everything other than what is definitively incumbent. They are of two types: a *Sunna* commanded or encouraged by the Messenger, or one that he performed himself, giving his community the choice to perform it; and a *Sunna* innovated by one member of the Community (*Umma*) and subsequently followed. The innovator receives the reward for it and the reward of all who act upon it.

### [The Fruit of Performing the Obligatory Duty in the Life of the Accountable Person]

When the servant performs the Obligatory Duty (*al-fard*) completely, he has fulfilled what Lordship (*al-Rububiyya*) demands of him in terms of Servitude (*al-'Ubuda*). The performance of the Obligatory Duty then yields for him a matter higher than the Real being his hearing. For the Real being the servant's hearing is a spiritual state (*hal*) belonging to the servant, and the ruling of the Obligatory Duty prevents him from attaining this state. [The higher matter] is that he becomes the hearing of the Real, so the Real hears through the servant. This is exemplified by His saying: "I was hungry, and you did not feed Me." As for this prevention (*haylula*) granted by the Obligatory Duty—preventing the Real from being his hearing—it is a verified and established station (*maqam*) as it is in reality. At that point, the servant knows that the Real is He, not himself. Whereas the possessor of the spiritual state (*sahib al-hal*) says, "I am [He]."

### [The Prophetic Sunna and the Sunan that are Approved Legislations after the Messenger of God]

The Supererogatory Acts (*al-sunan*) are paths of emulation (*iqtida'*). The highest of these is the emulation of the Real (*al-Haqq*) Himself, such that in the application of His Names to me, I am close to the Realization (*tahaqquq*) of them, not merely the adoption of their character (*takhalluq*). The lowest level, for the saint (*wali*), is the emulation of those concerning whom God said: <<أُولئِكَ الَّذِينَ هَدَى الله فَبِهُداهُمُ اقْتَدِهْ>> (Those are the ones whom Allah has guided, so follow their guidance). The scholars are the inheritors of the Prophets, and they inherited nothing but Knowledge (*al-'ilm*).

The Prophetic *Sunna* is of high station; it is the comprehensive adherence to the religion and its establishment, and the avoidance of division within it. It elevates the one who performs it and follows its path into the Muhammadan Presences (*al-Hadarat al-Muhammadiyya*) toward its goals in Gnosis (*al-ma'arif*), spiritual states (*al-ahwal*), and Theophany (*al-tajalli*). As for the *Sunan* which are approved legislations (*shara'i' mustahsana*) after the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him)—this is the approval (*istihsan*) recognized by the jurists, concerning which al-Shafi'i (may God have mercy on him) said: "Whoever approves [something] has legislated." The jurists took this statement from him as a form of censure. Yet, he (may God be pleased with him) spoke a reality that was legislated for him but was not understood by his contemporaries or those who came after him. He was one of the Four Pillars (*al-Awtad*), and his standing in the science of the Law (*'ilm al-Shar'*) veiled him from the people of his time and those who followed. We have narrated from some righteous people that one of them met al-Khidr and asked him, "What do you say about al-Shafi'i?" He replied, "He is one of the Pillars (*al-Awtad*)." He asked, "What do you say about Ahmad ibn Hanbal?" He replied, "A truthful man (*siddiq*)." He asked, "What do you say about Bishr al-Hafi?" He replied, "None like him was left after him." This is the testimony of al-Khidr concerning al-Shafi'i (may God have mercy on him).

### [The Law Permitted Good Innovation]

Since it was established for al-Shafi'i that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Whoever institutes a good *Sunna* (*sanna sunnatan hasana*), he shall have its reward and the reward of whoever acts upon it, and whoever institutes a bad *Sunna*..." (the rest of the Hadith), there is no doubt that the Law (*al-Shar'*) permitted him to institute a good *Sunna*. This is part of what he inherited from the Prophets, and it is "good," meaning the Real approves of it from him, and he instituted it. Thus, "Whoever approves [something]"—that is, whoever institutes a good *Sunna*—"has legislated." How astonishing is the lack of understanding among people regarding al-Shafi'i's statement on this matter, even though they affirm the ruling of the *mujtahid* (independent jurist) even if he errs in reality. The Lawgiver (*al-Shari'*) has confirmed it, and it is an acceptable legal ruling that no judge is permitted to reject. The principles and foundations of the Law uphold it, just like the Public Interests (*al-Masalih al-Mursala*) in the Maliki school.

### [Divine Choices in Existing Things and the Choices of the Prudent in Prescribed Matters]

Since the Lawgiver established its ruling generally and made clear that its institutor and those who follow him are rewarded, and that the ultimate destination of the followers is the institutor, according to his rank and the nature of what he instituted, I alert you by this to ensure that your times are filled with the Prophetic Laws (*al-shara'i' al-nabawiyya*) and the Original Supererogatory Acts (*al-sunan al-asliyya*). For the prudent person (*al-kayyis*) should not make the goal of his action anything but an Original Prophethood (*nubuwwa asliyya*), not a subsidiary one (*far'iyya*), since he has the choice in choosing, given that matters inherently accept choice, just as He (Exalted is He) did in all existing things (*al-mawjudat*). He chose a specific matter from every genus of things: He chose the word 'Allah' from the Beautiful Names (*al-Asma' al-Husna*). He chose the Messengers from mankind. He chose the Angels from the servants. He chose the Throne (*al-'Arsh*) from the celestial spheres (*al-aflak*). He chose Water from the elements (*al-arkan*). He chose Ramadan from the months. He chose Fasting from the acts of worship (*al-'ibadat*). He chose the Prophet's generation from the generations. He chose Friday from the days of the week. He chose the Night of Power (*Laylat al-Qadr*) from the nights. He chose the Obligatory Duties (*al-fara'id*) from the acts. He chose the number ninety-nine from the numbers. He chose Paradise (*al-Janna*) from the abodes. He chose the Vision (*al-Ru'ya*) from the states of bliss in Paradise. He chose Contentment (*al-Rida*) from the spiritual states (*al-ahwal*). He chose *La ilaha illa Allah* (There is no god but Allah) from the forms of remembrance (*al-adhkar*). He chose the Quran from speech. He chose Surah Ya Sin from the chapters of the Quran. He chose the Verse of the Throne (*Ayat al-Kursi*) from the verses of the Quran. He chose <<قُلْ هُوَ اللهُ أَحَدٌ>> (Say: He is Allah, the One) from the short chapters of the *Mufassal*. He chose the supplication of the Day of Arafah from the supplications of the seasons. He chose the Buraq from the mounts. He chose the Spirit (*al-Ruh*) from the Angels. He chose Whiteness (*al-Bayad*) from the colors. He chose Gathering (*al-Ijtima'*) from the existents (*al-akwan*). He chose the Heart (*al-Qalb*) from the human being. He chose the Black Stone (*al-Hajar al-Aswad*) from the stones. He chose the Frequented House (*al-Bayt al-Ma'mur*) from the houses. He chose the Lote Tree (*al-Sidra*) from the trees. He chose Mary and Asiya from women. He chose Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) from men. He chose the Sun from the planets. He chose the Straight Motion (*al-haraka al-mustaqima*) from the motions. He chose the Revealed Law (*al-Shari'a al-munazzala*) from the established norms (*al-nawamis*). He chose the Existential Proofs (*al-barahin al-wujudiyya*) from the proofs. He chose the Human Form (*al-suwar al-adamiyya*) from the forms, which is why He manifested it upon the Divine Form. He chose the Light (*al-anwar*) that accompanies vision (*al-nazar*). He chose Affirmation (*al-ithbat*) from the two opposites (*al-naqidhayn*). He chose Existence (*al-wujud*) from the two contraries (*al-diddain*). He chose Mercy (*al-Rahma*) over Wrath (*al-Ghadab*). He chose Prostration (*al-Sujud*) from the states of the acts of prayer. He chose the Remembrance of God (*dhikr Allah*) from the sayings of prayer. He chose Intention (*al-Niyya*) from the types of volitions, for it holds the ruling regarding the acceptance or rejection of the deed, for:

"Every person shall have what he intended."

And the non-doer is joined with the doer in reward and increase.

### [Choice of the Remembrance of God from the Sayings of Prayer]

As for the Remembrance of God (*dhikr Allah*) among the sayings of the prayer, the remembrance of God within it is the greatest thing in it, as He (Mighty and Majestic) said: <<إِنَّ الصَّلاةَ تَنْهى‏ عَنِ الْفَحْشاءِ والْمُنْكَرِ ولَذِكْرُ الله أَكْبَرُ>> (Indeed, the prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing, and the remembrance of Allah is greater). For the prayer is an intimate conversation (*munajat*), and the one who remembers God has the Real as his companion. If he remembers Him through Him, then He (Exalted is He) is his tongue.

### [Choice of Prostration from the Acts of Prayer]

As for His choice of Prostration (*al-Sujud*) among the acts of prayer, it is due to the protection it offers from Satan, for Satan does not leave the worshipper in any of the acts of prayer except specifically in the Prostration, because Prostration was his error. During Prostration, he weeps, regrets, and repents, and regret is repentance. That measure [of repentance] must be accepted. Thus, he repents at every prostration, and God loves every afflicted penitent.

Then he returns to temptation upon rising from the Prostration, and so on.

### [Choice of Mercy over Wrath]

As for His choice of Mercy (*al-Rahma*) over Wrath (*al-Ghadab*), it is because Mercy acts by Grace (*minna*) and acts by Necessity (*wujub*), and <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (It encompasses all things). Wrath is among the things that Mercy encompasses. Thus, there is no pure Wrath unmixed with Mercy, while Mercy is not mixed with Wrath. And <<مَن يَحْلِلْ عَلَيْهِ غَضَبِي فَقَدْ هَوَى>> (Upon whom My Wrath descends, he has fallen). Wrath causes him to fall (*hawa*). When he falls—which is the descent, the ruling of Wrath and nothing else—he falls into Mercy, which encompasses him and receives him. He falls only toward Mercy, and it is by the Mercy contained within the Wrath that he fell. It is Mercy that caused the Wrath to cast him down so that pure Mercy might receive him, like the mercy found in a bitter medicine, which the sick person drinks with aversion. There is a hidden mercy in it, due to which the bitter medicine is used at the time, leading him to recovery, which is pure Mercy. This is why the ultimate outcome is Mercy and its ruling. Even if they do not leave the Fire, they will have bliss within it, and <<وَاللهُ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (And Allah is over all things competent). Do you not see the benefits and comforts God has placed in the Fire of this world, even if it were only cauterization for certain ailments? It is the most decisive of remedies, and due to the strength of its effect, it casts doubt upon reliance on God (*tawakkul*) because it takes the place of the Healer and the Restorer of Health. Thus, Divine Jealousy (*ghayra*) ruled that the one who seeks cauterization is not fully reliant [on God].

### [Choice of Existence from the Two Contraries]

As for His choice of Existence (*al-wujud*) from the two contraries (*al-diddain*), it is because Existence is His Attribute (*sifa*). Thus, He chose His Attribute for the possibilities (*al-mumkinat*), and only this is correct. For He possesses Power (*al-Iqtidar*), and Power can only result in Existence. Do you not see that when He said: <<إِنْ يَشَأْ يُذْهِبْكُمْ>> (If He wills, He can do away with you), He then said: <<وَيَأْتِ بِآخَرِينَ>> (And bring others)? Power refused anything but Existence. He linked the Will (*al-Irada*) to non-existence (*al-i'dam*). He possesses the Name *al-Mani'* (The Preventer), and prevention is non-existence.

### [Choice of Affirmation over Negation]

As for His choice of Affirmation (*al-Ithbat*), it is the very essence of the thing to which He says "Be!" (*kun*). For, in its state of non-existence (*'adam*), He preferred Affirmation over Negation for it, so that it remains a possibility (*mumkin*) even in its state of non-existence. This is a subtle issue concerning preference in the state of non-existence, and it is due to the Essential Need (*al-iftiqar al-dhati*) inherent in the possible thing before Existence, when the Real wills it and hastens to it with the ruling of Affirmation that is incumbent upon it.

### [The Chosen Light from among the Lights]

As for the Chosen Light (*al-Nur*) from among the Lights, the Lights are veils (*hujub*). That is why He said concerning the Veiling Lights (*al-anwar al-hijabiyya*): "Light, I see it."

Then He promised the Vision (*al-Ru'ya*), and Vision is Light. Therefore, the Light in which He manifests to His servants must be chosen from those Veiling Lights, such as the Light of Oneness (*Nur al-Ahadiyya*), Glory (*al-'Izza*), Grandeur (*al-Kibriya'*), and Magnificence (*al-'Azama*). All of these are lifted from the sight, but their ruling remains in the heart. By their lifting, the Vision of the Real (Exalted is He) occurs, while their ruling remains in the heart, and the servants are annihilated (*fana*) from the Vision. Were it not so, they would witness their own selves when witnessing Him.

### [Choice of the Human Form]

As for His choice of the Human Form (*al-Sura al-Adamiyya*), it is because He created Adam upon His Form (*sura*). Thus, He applied all His Beautiful Names to him, and by the power of these Names, he bore the Trust (*al-Amana*) that was offered. This Reality granted him the ability to bear it, unlike the heavens, the earth, and the mountains, which refused to bear it. <<وَحَمَلَهَا الْإِنْسَانُ إِنَّهُ كَانَ ظَلُومًا>> (And man carried it. Indeed, he was wrongdoing) had he not carried it, <<جَهُولًا>> (ignorant) because the Gnosis of God (*al-'ilm bi-Allah*) is the very essence of ignorance concerning Him. The realization that one is incapable of grasping the comprehension is itself comprehension. For if he knows that there is something he does not know, then he has not known it. This is the knowledge that there is something unknowable, and his knowledge has no object except ignorance concerning it.

### [Choice of the Existential Proofs from the Dialectical and Other Proofs]

As for His choice of the Existential Proofs (*al-Barahin al-Wujudiyya*) over the Dialectical Proofs (*al-Barahin al-Jadaliyya*) and others, it is due to the complete knowledge they provide regarding the establishment of the Real (*thubut al-Haqq*) and the refutation of the opponent's argument. The Dialectical Proofs do not possess this strength; they refute the opponent's argument but may not establish a truth. The Sophistical Proofs (*al-Barahin al-Sufusta'iyya*) result in confusion, and in Divine Knowledge, they are closer to the Existential Proofs in one respect than the Dialectical Proofs.

### [Choice of the Revealed Law over the Philosophical Norms]

As for His choice of the Revealed Law (*al-Shari'a al-Munazzala*), it is due to its comprehensive connection to the Hereafter and the interests of this world. The Philosophical Norms (*al-Nawamis al-Hikmiyya*) established for the interests of this world and the continuation of good in the mundane realm do not possess the authority to rule upon God regarding Divine Proximity, the acceptance of deeds, the elevation of ranks, the establishment of Gardens, or the abode of misery. Only the Law revealed from God is sufficient for all of this. As for those who innovated acts of worship and observed them properly, seeking God's pleasure, which God had not prescribed for them—they are the people of a Law revealed from God, and they instituted good *Sunan* within it, appropriate to what the Lawgiver instituted through the Revealed Law concerning them, and He permitted them to institute [such acts]. As for the Philosophical Norms, they are not what these people instituted. This is why they are granted the reward.

### [Choice of the Straight Motion]

As for His choice of the Straight Motion (*al-Haraka al-Mustaqima*), it is because He is <<عَلَى صِرَاطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (upon a Straight Path), as He said about Himself. He singled out the human being, whom He created upon the Form of the Real, with this motion. The blessed person will be resurrected in this motion on the Day of Resurrection; it is for him in this world and the next. For the criminals will be resurrected inverted, which is the Inverted Motion (*al-Haraka al-Mankusa*), as He (Exalted is He) said concerning the criminals: <<وَلَوْ تَرَى إِذِ الْمُجْرِمُونَ نَاكِسُوا رُؤُوسِهِمْ عِنْدَ رَبِّهِمْ>> (And if you could but see when the criminals are hanging their heads before their Lord). The crooked, horizontal motion belongs to the beasts. Thus, the Straight Motion is only proper for the one whom God created upon the Form—that is, the Perfect Human (*al-Insan al-Kamil*)—who possesses this attribute in this world and the Hereafter. This is why Adam was specifically mentioned, as he is among the people of bliss for whom this Straight Motion remains, and for this reason, he was described as the Caliph (*Khalifa*).

### [Choice of the Sun]

As for His choice of the Sun, it is due to its provision of sustenance (*imdad*) to all the luminous planets, both high and low. This is why Abraham (peace be upon him) said: <<هَذَا أَكْبَرُ>> (This is greater). It is specifically located, according to both schools [of thought], in the heart of the sphere, which is the Fourth Heaven, where Idris (peace be upon him) resides. God mentioned that He raised him <<مَكَانًا عَلِيًّا>> (to a high place). The elevation of this place comes from its being the heart of the spheres, making it a high place by virtue of its status. What is above it, even if it is spatially lower [in relation to the sphere], is higher in distance and in relation to our heads. It is the Sun that brings about night and day through its rising and setting, for which God ordained the covering (*al-ghashayan*), which is the intercourse (*al-nikah*) and penetration (*al-ilaj*), leading to the manifestation of the essences of the generated things (*al-muwalladat*), and the creatures God brings forth in the night and day resulting from this penetration and covering. He made each of these two existents, resulting from the solar motion, pursue the other relentlessly, thereby manifesting the essences of contingent events (*al-hawadith*) through this pursuit.

### [His Choice of Muhammad]

As for His choice of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), it is due to the perfection and balance required by his temperament (*mizaj*) above all other human temperaments. Through this, he witnessed his prophethood while Adam was between water and clay. [His temperament] is differentiated in its parts within the elemental generated things (*al-muwalladat al-'unsuriyya*). This is a subtle issue known only to those who understand the extraction of the progeny (*al-dhurriyya*) from Adam's loins when <<أَشْهَدَهُمْ عَلَى أَنْفُسِهِمْ أَ لَسْتُ بِرَبِّكُمْ قَالُوا بَلَى>> (He made them testify concerning themselves, "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes"). This is the primordial nature (*al-fitra*) upon which people are born and to which they return. Concerning this gathering, he said:

"Souls are mobilized armies."

When He gathered them, He gathered them in the Presence of Representation (*Hadrat al-Tamthil*). Those who faced each other there became acquainted here, and those who turned their backs to each other there became estranged here, and similarly for those who were face-to-side, etc. Concerning this, I say:

> Indeed, hearts are mobilized armies,
> They appear in the Presence of Gathering, then they depart.
> Those that recognized each other are harmonious,
> And those that denied each other are discordant.

Everyone will affirm this testimony in the Hereafter and will not deny it or claim Lordship for himself. He (Exalted is He) says: <<إِذْ تَبَرَّأَ الَّذِينَ اتُّبِعُوا مِنَ الَّذِينَ اتَّبَعُوا>> (When those who were followed disassociate themselves from those who followed).

Thus, he (peace and blessings be upon him) was the greatest Divine Manifestation (*majla ilahi*). Through him, the knowledge of the first and the last was known. From the knowledge of the first was Adam's knowledge of the Names. Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was given the comprehensive words (*jawami' al-kalim*), and the Words of God are inexhaustible. He possesses the supremacy (*al-siyada*) that is not far from mankind on the Day of Resurrection, interceding for the intercessors—whether king, messenger, prophet, saint (*wali*), or believer—to intercede. He possesses the Praised Station (*al-Maqam al-Mahmud*) on the Witnessed Day.

### [Choice of Mary and Asiya]

As for His choice of Mary and Asiya, it is to attach them to the perfection (*al-kamal*) belonging to men, despite the existence of the degree (*daraja*) that men hold above them, for that degree is existential (*wujudiyya*) and does not vanish.

### [Choice of the Lote Tree]

As for His choice of the Lote Tree (*al-Sidra*), it is the place where the deeds of the servants terminate and the place of Grace (*al-Fadl*). The Forms of Deeds (*suwar al-a'mal*) take shelter in its shade. God covered it with Lights (*anwar*)—those Lights are the Lights of Deeds. No one can describe them. As we said, those Lights are the Lights of Deeds that emanate from their forms and cover the tree. No one can describe them, for description (*na't*) of things is a restriction and a distinction. Deeds differ and have levels (*maratib*), and their Lights are according to their levels: high, higher, luminous, and more luminous. Describing the high contradicts the higher, and describing the luminous opposes the more luminous, in terms of its being more luminous. Thus, it is not restricted by a description, for if you restrict it with one description, its opposite will invalidate it, and you will not have given it its due in description, since the Lights of Deeds are not of a single degree. These Lights have covered and concealed it. No one can reach its description. They, though they take shelter beneath it, have clothed it with garments of Lights, by which it is superior to all other trees. It is food and a washing agent, and its fruit (*nabiq*) is like large jars, from which the souls of the martyrs are provided sustenance.

### [Choice of the Frequented House]

As for His choice of the Frequented House (*al-Bayt al-Ma'mur*), it is because it is specifically populated by angels who are created every day from the drops of water of the River of Life (*Nahr al-Hayat*) that fall from the shaking of the Trustworthy Spirit (*al-Ruh al-Amin*). He immerses himself in the River of Life once every day for the creation of these angels who populate the Frequented House. They are seventy thousand angels who, once they leave it, never return. The secret remains in the place these angels populate, and there is no void (*khala'*). The entire cosmos (*al-'alam*) has filled the void. Search for this, for it is a magnificent knowledge that will lead you to the knowledge of the Transmutations of Essences (*istihalat al-a'yan*) within Essences and the transformation of Creation (*al-khalq*) through the stages. Then you will know <<أَنَّ اللهَ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (That Allah is over all things competent), but not over what is not a thing. For 'no-thing' (*la shay'*) does not accept thing-ness (*shay'iyya*), because if it accepted it, its reality would not be 'no-thing.' A known thing never departs from its reality. Thus, 'no-thing' is ruled as 'no-thing' forever, and what is a thing is ruled as a thing forever.

### [Choice of the Black Stone]

As for His choice of the Black Stone (*al-Hajar al-Aswad*), it is because He sent it down to establish it in the place of His Right Hand for the Divine Covenant (*al-Bay'a al-Ilahiyya*). For among the gnoses and acts of worship, there is nothing more adherent to what is known and what is worshipped than it. It was created upon pure Gnosis (*ma'rifa*) and pure Worship (*'ibada*), which the reality of plants and animals failed to achieve. This is why no part of it is found wholly in the human being. Everything in the human being accepts growth, which belongs to the plant kingdom, just as the animal possesses movement in directions. Whenever an existent departs from the mineral kingdom, it becomes mixed with the form of the claim to its reality. This is a subtle dispute that not every scholar perceives. Sahl drew attention to some of this, but he did not fulfill the matter as it truly is. I do not know whether he knew and was satisfied with what he mentioned, or whether God did not inform him of more than what he mentioned at that time. God knows best. Thus, God chose it as a Right Hand.

### [Choice of the Heart from the Human Being]

As for His choice of the Heart (*al-Qalb*) from the human being, it is that which encompasses Him, because it is every day in a [new] affair (*sha'n*). The 'day' is the measure of the breather's breath in singular time (*al-zaman al-fard*). It is called *qalb* (heart) because of its turning over (*taqallub*). Do you not see that it is between the two fingers of the All-Merciful (*al-Rahman*)? Only the All-Merciful turns it over. None of the other Names has any entry with Him concerning it. The Name *al-Rahman* grants only what is in its reality, for His Mercy <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompasses all things). There is no matter you see in its turning over that leads to distress, punishment, or misery, except that there is a hidden mercy within it, because it is turned over by the fingers of the All-Merciful. If He wills, He establishes it, and if He wills, He deviates it from that establishment. This deviation is relative. The heart inclines toward Mercy by the ruling of this Name that turns it over in deviation, just as it turns it over in establishment. This is good news from God to His servants: <<يَا عِبَادِيَ الَّذِينَ أَسْرَفُوا عَلَى أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (O My servants who have transgressed against themselves). He did not specify any transgression, thus encompassing all states of the transgressors in their transgression: <<لَا تَقْنَطُوا مِنْ رَحْمَةِ اللهِ>> (Do not despair of the Mercy of Allah). For the one who caused you to deviate is the finger of the All-Merciful. <<إِنَّ اللهَ يَغْفِرُ الذُّنُوبَ جَمِيعًا>> (Indeed, Allah forgives all sins). This is a statement that cannot be abrogated. This statement is reconciled with His saying: <<إِنَّ اللهَ لَا يَغْفِرُ أَنْ يُشْرَكَ بِهِ>> (Indeed, Allah does not forgive that association be made with Him). He holds accountable for association (*shirk*) as He wills, then the finger of the All-Merciful rules over him, and he returns to the All-Merciful. Other matters of deviation less than association are forgiven—some after punishment, and these are the people of major sins who exit the Fire through intercession after they have turned to charcoal, despite not being polytheists, and belief in this is obligatory. And some are forgiven initially without punishment. Thus, the ultimate outcome must be Mercy.

### [Choice of Gathering from the Existents]

As for His choice of Gathering (*al-Ijtima'*) from the existents (*al-akwan*), it grants separation (*iftiraq*) through distinction (*tamyiz*) within the very essence of Gathering. There must be a Lord (*Rabb*) and a creature (*marbub*), a Powerful One (*Qadir*) and a determined one (*maqdur*). Thus, Gathering is chosen and necessary due to the connection required by the realities of the Divine Names.

### [Choice of White from the Colors]

As for His choice of Whiteness (*al-Bayad*) from the colors, it is because all colors transform into it, but it does not transform into them. Rather, its whiteness is latent within it, concealed by the veil of the color that appears to the eye—such as black, red, yellow, and so on. Some of this is a color subsisting in the locus, and some is a color in the eye of the beholder, but not so in the essence of the colored object, such as the blackness of white mountains seen from afar. When you approach them, you see them as white, though you judged them to be black. You were mistaken in that judgment, yet correct in the appearance of blackness to you. The modality of this is unknown. Similarly, the blueness of the sky is only due to the eye's perception, even though its essence is a color different from blue.

### [Choice of the Spirit from the Angels]

As for His choice of the Spirit (*al-Ruh*) from the Angels, it is because it is the element breathed into every angelic, celestial, elemental, material, and natural form. Through it, things have life. It is the Spirit attributed to Him, and it is the Breath of the All-Merciful (*Nafas al-Rahman*), from which life proceeds. Life is bliss (*na'im*), and bliss is enjoyed. Enjoyment is according to the temperament (*mizaj*), as we said: the person who feels cold finds bliss in what causes the person who feels hot to suffer. Understand this. The Lawgiver's warning should suffice you, if you understand, that the Fire has people who belong to it, and Paradise has people who belong to it. He mentioned concerning the people of the Fire that they neither die therein nor live. They seek bliss through the Fire due to the presence of coldness. This is due to the ruling of temperament.

### [Choice of the Buraq from the Mounts]

As for His choice of the Buraq from the mounts, it is because it is the mount of the ascensions (*al-ma'arij*). It combines the characteristics of four-legged creatures and winged creatures; thus, it is celestial and terrestrial, like some animals that are both land and sea creatures.

### [Choice of the Supplication of the Day of Arafah]

As for His choice of the supplication of the Day of Arafah, it is a supplication made in a state of spiritual detachment (*tajrid*), humility, and submission, in a place of gnosis (*ma'rifa*) for a temporal day, due to its combination of night and day.

### [Choice of Qul Huwa Allah Ahad]

As for His choice of <<قُلْ هُوَ اللهُ أَحَدٌ>> (Say: He is Allah, the One), it is because it is specific to Him. It contains no mention of any existent (*kawn*) except the oneness (*ahadiyya*) of every single one, which does not resemble His Oneness (Exalted is He) specifically. The inclusion of this [created oneness] in this Surah contains a strange knowledge for whomever God opens it up. He began the Surah with His Oneness and concluded it with the oneness of the created beings. Know that the existents (*al-ka'inat*) are linked to Him by the link of the last to the first, not the link of the first to the last. For the last seeks the first, but the first does not seek the last. He is the Self-Sufficient (*al-Ghaniyy*) from the worlds by His Essence (*dhat*), and the last seeks Him through the designation *Allah*, described by Oneness (*al-Ahadiyya*). I have alerted you to the source of this knowledge contained in this Surah through the subsequent Oneness, which, despite its link to the First, does not resemble it, because it seeks Him, and He does not seek it: <<أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَرَاءُ إِلَى اللهِ وَاللهُ هُوَ الْغَنِيُّ الْحَمِيدُ>> (You are the needy toward Allah, while Allah is the Self-Sufficient, the Praiseworthy).

### [Choice of Ayat al-Kursi]

As for His choice of the Verse of the Throne (*Ayat al-Kursi*) from the verses (*ayat*), the verses are signs (*'alamat*), and nothing indicates a thing better than the thing itself. This Verse of the Throne is entirely His Names or His Attributes. This is not found in any other verse. Thus, He indicated Himself by Himself: <<اللهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (Allah, there is no god but He)—He negated and affirmed using a pronoun of absence referring to a present Name with an absent referent. <<الْحَيُّ>> (The Ever-Living) is a conditional attribute for the existence of what belongs to Him of the Names. <<الْقَيُّومُ>> (The Sustainer) over everything other than Him by what it earns, for He <<أَعْطَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (gave everything its creation). <<لَا تَأْخُذُهُ سِنَةٌ وَلَا نَوْمٌ>> (Neither slumber nor sleep overtakes Him)—an attribute of transcendence (*tanzih*) from what contradicts the preservation of the cosmos, which, were it not for His Sustaining, would not remain for a single moment. The pronoun in <<لَهُ مَا فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَمَا فِي الْأَرْضِ>> (To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth) refers back to Him, and it is a pronoun of absence, indicating His ownership and the determined preservation of the servant for the continuation of the ruling of Divinity (*al-Uluhiyya*). <<مَنْ ذَا الَّذِي يَشْفَعُ>> (Who is it that can intercede)—the intercession of the singular (*al-witr*) by the ruling <<عِنْدَهُ>> (with Him)—a pronoun of absence—indicating the lack of independence in ruling apart from Him. His permission is necessary, since there is an intercessor or intercessors. <<يَعْلَمُ مَا بَيْنَ أَيْدِيهِمْ>> (He knows what is before them)—which is the state they are in—<<وَمَا خَلْفَهُمْ>> (and what is behind them)—which is what they will return to. <<وَلَا يُحِيطُونَ بِشَيْءٍ مِنْ عِلْمِهِ>> (And they encompass not a thing of His knowledge) of things <<إِلَّا بِمَا شَاءَ>> (except for what He wills) of it, not all of it. <<وَسِعَ كُرْسِيُّهُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ>> (His Kursi encompasses the heavens and the earth)—the high and the low. <<وَلَا يَئُودُهُ>> (And He is not wearied by) <<حِفْظُهُمَا>> (their preservation), because it is an essential, conceptual preservation, a hidden provision (*imdad ghaybi*), and a continuous creation in the low and the high. <<وَهُوَ>> (And He)—a pronoun of absence—<<الْعَلِيُّ>> (The Most High) by His self-sufficiency from His creation by His Essence. <<الْعَظِيمُ>> (The Magnificent) in the hearts of the Gnostics (*al-'arifin*) by His Majesty (*jalal*). Thus, He has awe (*hayba*) within them. It is a verse in which the remembrance of God is mentioned sixteen times, alternating between an explicit Name and a pronoun. You will not find this in any other verse. Five of these are explicit Names: Allah, The Ever-Living, The Sustainer, The Most High, The Magnificent. Nine of them are explicit pronouns, thus implicit in the explicit form. Two of them are implicit in the inner reality, having no explicit form: the pronoun of Knowledge (*al-'ilm*) and the Will (*al-Mashi'a*). Similarly, His Knowledge and His Will are known only to Him. No one knows what is in His Knowledge or what is in His Will except after the manifestation of the known thing through the occurrence of the willed thing, and nothing else. Therefore, the pronoun did not appear in them.

### [Choice of Ya Sin from the Quran]

As for His choice of Ya Sin from the Quran, it is because it is the heart of the Quran. Whoever recites it is like one who has recited the Quran ten times. The heart is the noblest part of the human form (*al-sura al-sadiyya*). Similarly, the Surah of the Sin (*al-sura al-siniyya*) is the revealed one. It has, among the constellations, the house of the Sun's exaltation, which is the sign of primacy (*al-awwaliyya*), the time of spring, the flourishing of growth, the manifestation of creation's beginning, and the refinement of the vapors of breaths that the time of winter had condensed due to the coldness of the atmosphere. [Winter] used to cause freezing in the vapors exiting the breathers; when they exited, it condensed them, then returned them as water—which is the dampness you find on your hands when you breathe into them in winter. He possesses the Divine Affairs (*al-shu'un al-ilahiyya*) in which He remains in every breath, Glorious is His Majesty.

### [Choice of the Quran from Divine Speech]

As for His choice of the Quran from Divine Speech (*al-Kalam al-Ilahi*), it is that which possesses the attribute of Gathering (*al-Jam'*). Within Gathering is the very essence of the Criterion (*al-Furqan*), for Gathering is the proof of Multiplicity (*al-Kathra*), and Multiplicity consists of units (*ahad*), which is the very essence of separation (*iftiraq*) within the very essence of Gathering. Thus, it is the Criterion, the Quran.

### [Choice of La ilaha illa Allah from the Forms of Remembrance]

As for His choice of *La ilaha illa Allah* (There is no god but Allah), it is a remembrance that encompasses Negation (*al-Nafy*) and Affirmation (*al-Ithbat*), which is not the case for any other form of remembrance.

### [Choice of Contentment from the Spiritual States]

As for His choice of Contentment (*al-Rida*) from the spiritual states (*al-ahwal*), it is the last thing that comes from the Real as good tidings (*bushra*) for the people of bliss. There are no good tidings after it, for it is a good tiding that accompanies eternity, as mentioned in the narration. It is a good tiding given by God to them on the Dune (*al-Kathib*) during the Vision (*al-Ru'ya*) at the Greatest Gathering (*al-Zawr al-A'zam*), not after the people return from the Vision.

### [Choice of Paradise]

As for His choice of Paradise (*al-Janna*), it is the abode of the permanence of bliss and vision, shielding its inhabitants from every disliked thing that occurs in the abode opposite to it, and from what the authority of the Names of Retribution (*Asma' al-Intiqam*) dictates.

### [Choice of Vision]

As for His choice of the Vision (*al-Ru'ya*), it is the ultimate goal of sight. Visual pleasure is unmatched by any other pleasure, for it is the certainty of conviction (*'ayn al-yaqin*) in the Worshipped One (*al-Ma'bud*).

### [Choice of the Number Ninety-Nine from the Numbers]

As for His choice of the number ninety-nine from the numbers, it is because it is the odd number (*witr*) of the Names, combining the units (*al-ahad*) and the tens (*al-'aqd*). "God has ninety-nine Names, one hundred minus one. Whoever enumerates them shall enter Paradise" merely by enumeration—memorization, recitation, and comprehension. For God is Odd (*Witr*) and loves the odd number.

### [Choice of the Obligatory Duties]

As for His choice of the Obligatory Duties (*al-fara'id*), their result is that the servant becomes the attribute of the Real: His hearing and His sight. For the love of the Supererogatory Acts (*al-nawafil*) grants that the Real becomes the servant's hearing and sight. The Supererogatory Act is only in a degree lower than the Obligatory Duty (*al-fard*). The Obligatory Duty has primacy. The Real does not descend to the level of being the servant's hearing, as required by His Majesty (*Jalal*). Rather, God must descend with His Attribute, which is the servant being the attribute of the Real, due to the Form upon which he was created. This [Form] is cut off from the Divine Form, just as the womb (*al-rahm*) is a branch (*shijna*) of the All-Merciful (*al-Rahman*). The Obligatory Duty (*al-fard*) is the cutting (*al-qat'*). When the servant performs it, it becomes manifest to him that he is an attribute of the Real. If he performs a Supererogatory Act, the Real becomes his attribute. Thus, the Obligatory Duty is distinguished from the Supererogatory Act, and the higher degree belongs to the Obligatory Duty. Were it not for what the Obligatory Duty grants, it would not be established that He says:

"I was hungry, and you did not feed Me."

"I am most eager to meet My servant who desires Me."

"He is nearer to Us than the jugular vein."

"I have not hesitated concerning anything I am about to do..."

And similar Divine communications.

### [Choice of Laylat al-Qadr from the Other Nights]

As for His choice of the Night of Power (*Laylat al-Qadr*) from all other nights, it is because matters are only distinguished by their measures (*aqdar*) in the sight of the Real (*al-Haqq*). The Real is Unseen (*Ghayb*), so He specifically assigned the measure (*al-qadr*) to the night, because the night is a veil (*satr*), just as the Unseen is veiled.

### [Choice of Friday from the Days]

As for His choice of Friday (*Yawm al-Jumu'a*) from the days, it is because the two Forms (*al-suratan*) appeared in it. God made that day for the forms. It is the fifth month for the dropping of the sperm. It is a feminine day, possessing adornment and the completion of creation. God chose within it an hour of its hours, which is like the dot (*al-nukta*) in the mirror. This is the place of the image of the Manifesting One (*al-Mutajalli*) in the mirror of the day, where He sees Himself. The address and the obligation (*al-taklif*) occur based on the Form that appears between the mirror and the viewer. Through it arise the demonstrative pronouns (*asma' al-isharat*)—such as *dha*, *dhan*, *ta*, *tan*, and *ula'*—and the personal pronouns (*asma' al-dama'ir*)—such as *huwa*, *hiya*, *huma*, *hum*, *hunna*, *ka*, *kuma*, *kum*, *kunna*, *anta*, *anti*, *antuma*, *antum*, *antunna*, and the *ya'* pronoun of the first person singular, which affects its subject (*aniyya*) unless the *Nun* of Protection (*Nun al-Wiqaya*) guards it. It must have an effect, either on the subject or on the *Nun* of Protection; it is necessary. For this reason, the *Nun* of Protection possesses spiritual chivalry (*futuwwa*) and altruism (*ithar*) from the world of letters. This is why it is called the *Nun* of Protection. It holds a status like the *Kaf* in His saying, "I seek refuge in You (*a'udhu bi-ka*)." Concerning it, I say:

> The *Nun* of Protection is a *Nun* that nothing resembles
> In Existence, save fasting and good character (*khalaq*).
> Spiritual chivalry and altruism are its origin,
> So we have no protector in the word other than it.
> Half of Existence belongs to it, by the attribute of its Creator,
> In status, thus it is the Permanent, the Abiding.

### [Choice of the Three Generations in Order]

As for His choice of the three generations (*al-qurun*) in order, the first of these is due to the manifestation of the perfection of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), both unseen and witnessed. He instituted the Law himself, abrogated what had been the *Sunna* of his deputies by his presence, confirmed what he confirmed, and affirmed belief in all of it—what was abrogated and what was not. This is the first generation. Then two generations followed him. All of them are people of spiritual opening (*fath*) and manifestation, holding the status of the three white blazes (*al-ghurar*) of every month. He (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "A group of people will wage war, and it will be said, 'Is there among you anyone who saw the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him)?' They will say, 'Yes,' and they will be granted victory (*fath*). This is the first generation. Then a group of people will wage war, and it will be said, 'Is there among you anyone who saw someone who saw the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him)?' They will say, 'Yes,' and they will be granted victory. This is the second generation. Then a group of people will wage war, and it will be said, 'Is there among you anyone who saw someone who saw someone who saw the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him)?' They will say, 'Yes,' and they will be granted victory. This is the third generation." He (peace and blessings be upon him) did not add more than this. This is because there is nothing besides the Divine Presence (*al-Hadra al-Ilahiyya*), which is an expression for the Essence (*al-Dhat*), the Attributes (*al-Sifat*), and the Acts (*al-Af'al*). This is the meaning of "the best of generations." Through the providence of the first generation, the opening was granted to all. This is the Essence of the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him), and the power of his light and the authority of his manifestation granted the Divine Opening (*al-Fath al-Ilahi*) to whoever saw him, or saw whoever saw him, or saw whoever saw whoever saw him. This is His saying: "The best of generations is my generation, then those who follow them, then those who follow them."

We only likened them to the three white blazes of the month and likened the time of his call to a month because people differed on the measure of a generation (*qarn*) in time. Among their sayings is that a generation is thirty years. For this reason, we placed the three generations, from the time of his call until the Day of Resurrection, in the status of a month, and made the three generations like the three white blazes of it.

### [Choice of Fasting from the Acts of Worship]

As for His choice of Fasting (*al-Sawm*) from the acts of worship:

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to a person who asked him, "Hold fast to fasting, for there is nothing like it."

He negated likeness (*mithliyya*) for fasting, thus resembling <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like Him). And He said, "Fasting is for Me."

He made all other acts of worship for the human being, since fasting is an attribute of Transcendence (*tanzih*), and Transcendence is only fitting for Him (Exalted is He).

### [Choice of Ramadan from the Months]

As for His choice of the month of Ramadan from the months, it is due to its participation in the Name, for Ramadan is one of the Divine Names. Thus, a sanctity was determined for it that does not belong to the rest of the months of the year. He made it one of the lunar months so that its blessing might encompass all the months of the year, manifesting in every month of the year, so that every day of the year receives a share of it. The best months, in our view, are Ramadan, then Rabi' al-Awwal, then Rajab, then Sha'ban, then Dhu al-Hijja, then Shawwal, then Dhu al-Qa'da, then Muharram. My knowledge concerning the virtue of the lunar months ends here. The order of virtue for the remaining lunar months—Safar, Rabi' al-Akhir, Jumada al-Ula, and Jumada al-Akhira—was left ambiguous to me. I do not have knowledge of the order of their virtue, or whether they are equal in virtue, which is what I predominantly suspect. He manifested that, but I did not verify it, so I cannot say what I do not have knowledge of. God knows best.

### [Choice of Water from the Elements]

As for His choice of the element Water (*al-Ma'*) from the elements (*al-arkan*), it is because He made every living thing from water. Even the Throne (*al-'Arsh*), when He created it, was not above water. Life flowed into it from water, making it the Greatest Element (*al-Rukn al-A'zam*), just as He said, "Hajj is Arafah." Although the cause of life involves other things alongside water, water is the Greatest Element among those things.

### [Choice of the Throne from the Celestial Spheres]

As for His choice of the Throne (*al-'Arsh*) from the celestial spheres (*al-aflak*), it is because it encompasses all bodies, and <<وَاللهُ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ مُحِيطٌ>> (And Allah is encompassing of all things). It has primacy (*al-awwaliyya*) among the spheres, and what is beneath it. Thus, it is the First, the Encompassing. He chose it for the settling (*al-istiwa'*) due to the connection between the two attributes. If the Throne is the Kingdom (*al-Mulk*), then it is more fitting that it be chosen without choice, because there is nothing but God and His Kingdom, and everything other than Him is His Kingdom. However, a distinction of the Throne from others has been narrated, so it is determined to be chosen for its primacy and encompassing nature, because the heavens and the earth are within the *Kursi* (Footstool) like a ring in a desert, and the *Kursi* is within the Throne like a ring in a desert.

### [Choice of the Angels from the Servants]

He chose the Angels from the servants, for they are created from Light (*Nur*). Their bodies are essentially luminous, making them closer in proportion than other creatures to the Divine Light (*al-Nur al-Ilahi*). For this reason,

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him) used to supplicate that God make him Light,

due to his knowledge of the darkness of nature (*zulmat al-tabi'a*).

### [Choice of the Cloud/Mist from the Where-nesses]

He chose the Cloud (*al-'Ama'*) from the Where-nesses (*al-ayniyyat*), and He was in it before the creation of creation. From it, He created the Bewildered Angels (*al-Mala'ika al-Muhayyima*), who are bewildered in His Majesty (*Jalal*). Then He created creation, and their bewilderment in the Majesty of His Beauty (*Jalal Jamalihi*) preoccupied them from seeing anything other than Him. They are those who do not know that God created anyone else. What a noble state this is! Thus, He made the Cloud a Where-ness for Him, the Throne a place of settling for Him, the lowest heaven a place for His descent, and the earth for His accompaniment. He is with us wherever we are.

### [Choice of the Messengers from Mankind]

He chose the Messengers (*al-Rusul*) from mankind to convey from God what the matter truly is. He only brought them forth for the sake of Gnosis of Him, because He loved to be known. He introduced Himself to them through the Messengers, by the books and scriptures He sent down with them. They knew Him with an essential gnosis (*ma'rifa dhatiyya*), just as they knew Him through the intellects (*al-'uqul*) He created for them and gave the power of speculative thought (*al-nazar al-fikri*). They knew Him through proofs and demonstrations with an existential, negative gnosis (*ma'rifa wujudiyya salbiyya*). The intellect, in its independence, could not achieve more than this. Then, the Messengers came afterward with essential gnosis. Thus, creation worshipped the God who introduced Himself to them through His Law (*shar'*) because the intellect does not provide any act of worship, any means of proximity (*qurba*), or any affirmative essential attribute (*sifa dhatiyya thubutiyya*) for the Real. The only share the intellect has in the Law, which its proof can independently establish, is <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like Him), with the addition of the *kaf* [in *ka-mithlihi*], not by affirming it as an attribute. Thus, He chose the Messengers to convey what the intellect cannot independently grasp of the knowledge of His Essence, and of the deeds, abstentions, and relationships that bring proximity to Him.

### [Choice of the Name Allah from the Beautiful Names]

He chose the Name *Allah* from the Beautiful Names (*al-Asma' al-Husna*) and established it in the words in its proper place. It is the Name that is described but does not describe. All Names are its descriptions, but it is not a description. For this reason, derivation (*ishtiqaq*) is forced upon it. It is a static, proper noun (*'alam jamid*) designated for the Essence (*al-Dhat*) in the world of words and letters. No one else (Glorious and Exalted is He) is named by it. Thus, He protected it from being shared, just as He indicated that there is no god other than Him.

### [The Divine Choices are a Call to the Intellects for Choice, which is Reflection and Insight]

We have mentioned these Divine Choices (*al-Ikhtiyarat al-Ilahiyya*) as an alert to the heedless intellects concerning what they are called to: reflection (*i'tibar*) and insight (*istibsar*). We have not exhausted the matter completely, for we do not know the details of what God created of existing things by way of comprehensive knowledge, even though we are able, by God's empowerment, to confine the existing things, which includes everything. We only intended here to know the individual things He chose and selected from every type of the limited creatures in Existence—those subsisting by themselves and those not subsisting by themselves, the localized and the non-localized, and the type that accepts localization only by dependence, and what is composed of these and what is not composed. The divisions of the cosmos and existing things are confined to what we have mentioned.

### [What the Intellect Can Independently Choose and What is Beyond Its Level]

There is a relative detail that the intellect can independently establish: the preference of things over one another by distinguishing their levels (*maratib*), the influence of some upon others, the effect of some upon others, and the dependence of some upon others. However, the preference of Divine Proximity (*al-Qurb al-Ilahi*) through His Providence toward them, rather than what their realities dictate, can only be achieved by God informing us through the sciences of inspiration (*'ulum al-ilham*) He places in our hearts, or through what reaches us of this in the revealed books and Prophetic communications. There is no other way besides this.

### [Intellectual Indications, Legal Definitions, and Essential Worship]

The Supererogatory Acts (*al-sunan*) are the intellectual indications (*al-dalalat al-'aqliyya*) because they are paths. The Obligatory Duties (*al-fara'id*) are the legal definitions (*al-ta'rifat al-shar'iyya*) concerning what the Real (Exalted is He) is, in relation to Himself and in relation to His creation. So worship God, O servants of God, according to the description He gave of Himself in His Book or upon the tongues of His Messengers, without addition or omission, and without interpretation (*ta'wil*) that leads to deficiency or excess. Rather, submit to Him (Glorious is His Majesty) what He described Himself with, even if it seems impossible or contradictory. That is due to our deficiency and ignorance of the true state of the matter. We have fulfilled what the speculative intellectual power grants of knowledge concerning His Existence and the truthfulness of those who convey from Him (Exalted is He) what He revealed to His servants. We say: Acceptance without objection, even if the matter contradicts or seems impossible. For what is essentially unknown to the intellect—how can it enter into what relates to His Essence concerning necessity, possibility, or impossibility? The intellect must not exceed its limit, and it must submit to Him (Exalted is He) what He revealed and informed us of concerning Himself. For God <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (Speaks the truth, and He guides to the way). We must believe in Him and in what came from Him, based on His knowledge of it, in a Book or upon the tongue of a Messenger. May God grant us success in adhering to that, for none perishes concerning God except the doomed. End of the Ninety-Fifth Part.

(In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)
